turn.text: That is if there were voluntary compliance, an injunction would be necessary and that was Hecht against Bowles?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: That was precisely in the Hecht case.
Yes, Your Honor.
The Hecht case said if compliance with congressional statute would otherwise be achieved, the court of course need not issue an injunction.

We will be pleased if an injunction would not have been necessary in this case, because in 1973 when all options were fully open, although Congress appears to indicate and the GAO study indicates that option still are open today, we will be in a much better position to review the question.
Yes, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: May I come back to the argument you are making a few minutes ago that this dam after all is not important to what Congress intended.
I read a few words from the Senate Appropriations Committee Report last year.
The project will provide needed flood control, water supply, recreational opportunities, and improved navigation.
Now, without the dam and the water in it, will any of those objectives of Congress be attainable?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Your Honor, it should be noted that the Appropriations Committee at no time has ever reviewed the GAO study, the reviews taking place in the other committees, and so on.
It turns out --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: That was not my question?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Your Honor, it is true that there would be no flood control and there would be no electric power in the project.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: No recreation?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: No, that is not so, Your Honor.
The river is the last place left in the river system that has high quality water conditions.
It is the finest trout stream in the southeast of the United States.
People come from Alabama, Georgia, and all over to fish because --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: You have Justice Stewart's vote already.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Your Honor, it is the last place for flowing water recreation, as the GAO noted, because there had been so many impoundments --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Do you think the Senate of the United States or the Senate Appropriations Committee was thinking about maintaining the streams when it was appropriating money to close the dam?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Your Honor, I -- I believe that the relevant discussion is in the committee that has law-making jurisdiction over the Act and they clearly are concerned about recreation, and the house side as well.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Is there any record that the members of that committee voted against this appropriation?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Your Honor, the appropriations bill, on its face, does not purport to treat Tellico.
It says nothing about Tellico.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I understand that the bill on its face does not, but do you think any -- any rational person could read the reports of the committees for the last four or five years and conclude that there was any intention on the part of Congress other than to complete this project?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Your Honor, I believe that one reading those reports would find clearly and specifically that indeed Congress had no intent to amend the Act, and that is one of the requirements for taking an appropriations bill or an appropriations committee report and reading out of it an informal implied amendment.

There must be some indication of an intent to amend and as a matter of fact in 1977, Your Honor, Senator Stennis specifically said “if we put such an amendment in here it would be subject to a point of order.”

I think Your Honor’s question, however, reflects the fact that certainly the appropriations committee or certain members of it probably did not agree with the Endangered Species Act or wished that it did not apply in this case, but there was no intention expressed to amend and that is the only basis upon which we could use that to change the law.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Do you think that reflects any indication on the part of Congress not to construe Section 7 as applying to completed projects?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: I believe, Your Honor, that the appropriations bill as every appropriations bill is passed, presumes that the agency will comply with all applicable relevant law.
The agencies are creatures of Congress.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: You kind of did not hear my question so I will put another one to you.

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Is it still your position, as I understand it, that this Act, Section 7, applies to completed projects?
I know you say you do not think it will occur very often, but there will be a need to apply, but does it apply if the need exists?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: To the continuation of --?

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: To completed projects.
Take the Grand Cooley Dam?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Your Honor, if there were species there --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I am not -- I am not asking --

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: -- it would not be endangered by the dam.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I know.
That is your view.
I am asking you --

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: I see Your Honor --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: -- not to project your imagination into the future beyond accepting my assumption and that is that an endangered specie might turn up at Grand Cooley, does Section 7 apply to it?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: I believe it would, Your Honor.
The Secretary of the Interior --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: That is your answer to my question.

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Yes, it would.
The consequences of that of course --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: In what respects, Mr. Plater, would it apply?
It would apply only to future action, would it not?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Well, Your Honor as we --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The statute does not ever require anybody to tear anything down, does it, no matter how --?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: It certainly says nothing about that in the Act, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It certainly cannot conduct certain actions in the future if they are going to extinguish the species, that is what it says.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But actions might be the continued operation of a dam?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Or raising and lowering of the water which is done on cyclical level --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But there is nothing that would require you to tear a dam down?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: If that situation would arise, Your Honor, it would probably be a biological rarity in the sense that if the species comes when the water goes up and down then it is established there and it is not endangered.

Maybe the way to answer this is on the basis of the administrative record, because in the hearings last summer, the Culver hearings in the senate, it was again and again noted that the biological expertise of the Department of Interior is capable of handling many sophisticated such questions and there has never been a case that could not resolved through good faith in administrative consultation.
There had been 4,500 potential conflicts.
There had been hundreds of actual conflicts, but only TVA testified that the Act was unworkable.
Every other administrative agency said that although the Act sometimes was a bother, that they could resolve these conflicts.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why do you not rely on the fact that even though a facility is all built, if you knew about it when you started building, is that what you say here?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: That was the situation in this case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is what I mean --

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: In 1973, TVA knew about it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You are not (Voice Overlap), are you?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: No, of course not, Your Honor.
[Laughte]Thank you for reminding me.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When this litigation first began to block the development of the project, there was no snail darter problem at all, was there?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: The Nipa (Ph) suit Your Honor, which was filed in 1971 noted that there possibly were endangered species in the river.
TVA had noticed, bu, at that time of course, Your Honor, it was the old Act which allowed TVA to have the discretionary flexibility that now they are trying to read into this Act, applied.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Then the snail darter was discovered and it became a handy handle to hold on to?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Your Honor, the question of the snail darter clearly went specifically to the qualities of this habitat, that is as you suggest, the citizens have been concerned about for years.
That is to say, the last free flowing clear -- clear such big river left in the region.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I am sure they just do not want this project for a combination of plaintiffs?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: There are combinations of plaintiffs in this case, many with different points of view.

As I note, the snail darter is integral to the environmental conservation balance question which has been litigated over the years, but one of our plaintiffs, for instance, is the association of southeastern biologists has no interest for conservation purposes, but for biological purposes, it is taking what I believe is its first public stand to show that a biological statute of Congress is important to be enforced.
The agency should not violate the law with impunity.
As a matter of fact, Your Honor, that is where we would leave the case.
The Act is working on the record except in this case.
This is the only agency that is persistently declined to comply with the law and of course, in 1973, there were all options open.
That is the relevant time to question when indeed TVA should have looked at this Act and decided that it like every other federal agency, would abide by the law.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Plater, I understand what your position is and what the law means, but if somebody happen to disagree with you as to how to construe the Act, it might be that the agency is not violating the law at all?
Your argument is what the law means?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Only TVA is making that argument.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, nevertheless, your statement is absolutely incorrect if the Act is not -- unless the Act is construed the way you say it should be construed?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, if this Act is discretionary, the way the old law was written, if this Act does not mean what it says then, indeed, this lawsuit was false.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But one of the issue in this case is what does the Act mean?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: The regulations of the Department of Interior, every holding in the case so far, and every other agency.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I understand you are arguing that it should be construed in a certain way?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But, some other people disagree with you?

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Yes, they do.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: zygmunt_j_b_plater
turn.label: Mr. Zygmunt J. B. Plater
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
